text:
The file is ref.var.html - a standard php4 documentation file.

Rename the file to ref-var.html and then Apache serves the file, all is well!
This is a funny bug! If it really is an Apache bug then somebody should have
noticed before me, but the world is not like that.

I have built the server today without any patches.

The server error_log says:

[Wed Mar 02 21:50:20 2005] [error] [client 83.73.64.174] Syntax error in type
map, no ':' in /var/www/html/manual/mod/mod_php4/ref.var.html for header
<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.01 transitional//en">\n

Which is strange to me. Lynx and tidy syntax check says the ref.var.html file
is ok - and as said above WHEN THE FILE IS RENAMED THERE IS NO PROBLEM!
There are bunches of other ref.something.html which all work ok.

Regards/Donald Axel
creator: donald@d-axel.dk
rici@ricilake.net
text:
I suspect what is happening is that your configuration file has an applicable AddHandler directive 
mapping the .var file extension to the type-map handler. See <http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/
mod/mod_mime.html#multipleext> and <http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/mod/
mod_negotiation.html#typemaps>for more information.

If this is the case, you can fix it by putting the directive:

RemoveHandler .var

into a <Directory> section for the directory in which the ref.var.html file lives.

creator: donald@d-axel.dk
text:
(In reply to comment #1)

Thank you very much! 

I can see I should have figured this one out.
How nice to get help! You have saved my day.

Donald Axel
